citations.narrative:
In December 2023 the veterinary clinic HVAC system stopped heating the building properly. After a HVAC professionals
and electricians were consulted, it was determined that the current HVAC system couldn’t consistently heat the building
without additional repairs and replacements. In the interim, space heaters were used in all rooms housing animals and
temperatures were checked.
On January 17, 2024, during a cold snap, the temperature in the macaw room dropped to 49 degrees with a space heater
in the room. A heat bulb was immediately added to facilitate heating the room to an appropriate temperature for the birds.
During a routine check, 1.5hrs after the bulb was placed, the green-winged macaw “Mac” was found non-responsive on
the floor of the cage and efforts to revive him were unsuccessful. His body temperature was normal. Soon after, the
keeper noted that "Popcorn", the blue-throated macaw, "eyes rolled up in his head". He went into respiratory distress and
was unable to be revived. The heat bulb was examined. A film was on the bulb appeared to have a burn defect in a
couple of areas. The same type of bulb was used in other bird areas. They were checked and no defects were noted on
the film of those bulbs. It was determined that the macaws succumbed to the toxic fumes released from the burning of the
film on the bulb.
Animals must be handled in a manner that does not cause unnecessary discomfort or physical harm. Corrected at the
time of inspection by implementing appropriate corrective actions that included replacing all heat bulbs, in areas housing
birds, with radiant heaters and central heat was restored and is properly working in the veterinary clinic.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.131(b)(1)  Critical Repeat
   
Handling of animals. 
In December 2023 the veterinary clinic HVAC system stopped heating the building properly. After a HVAC professionals 
and electricians were consulted, it was determined that the current HVAC system couldn’t consistently heat the building 
without additional repairs and replacements. In the interim, space heaters were used in all rooms housing animals and 
temperatures were checked.  
 
On January 17, 2024, during a cold snap, the temperature in the macaw room dropped to 49 degrees with a space heater 
in the room. A heat bulb was immediately added to facilitate heating the room to an appropriate temperature for the birds. 
During a routine check, 1.5hrs after the bulb was placed, the green-winged macaw “Mac” was found non-responsive on 
the floor of the cage and efforts to revive him were unsuccessful. His body temperature was normal. Soon after, the 
keeper noted that "Popcorn", the blue-throated macaw, "eyes rolled up in his head". He went into respiratory distress and 
was unable to be revived. The heat bulb was examined. A film was on the bulb appeared to have a burn defect in a 
couple of areas. The same type of bulb was used in other bird areas. They were checked and no defects were noted on 
the film of those bulbs. It was determined that the macaws succumbed to the toxic fumes released from the burning of the 
film on the bulb.  
 
Animals must be handled in a manner that does not cause unnecessary discomfort or physical harm. Corrected at the 
time of inspection by implementing appropriate corrective actions that included replacing all heat bulbs, in areas housing 
birds, with radiant heaters and central heat was restored and is properly working in the veterinary clinic. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
